Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Story: I glanced at my phone, a message from Mark lighting up the screen. He was moving to a new apartment this weekend and needed help with a few heavy boxes. “Could you spare a couple of hours?” he asked. As an acquaintance, I felt the familiar tug of obligation—helping out was the right thing to do, and I knew he didn’t have many people to call on. But as I read his message, my calendar notification chimed: the national continuing education program for pharmacists was scheduled for the same day. It was a rare, in-person event, crucial for maintaining my licensure and staying current with new treatments. My manager had emphasized its importance, and I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss it. The weight of both expectations pressed on me—Mark’s hope for support, my professional duty to stay updated. I stared at the two commitments, feeling the tension coil in my chest, torn between being a helpful friend and a responsible pharmacist.
